issues.text: Whether the contract was void for illegality on account of clauses 6 and 7 contravening the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act and import control laws

anchor.surface_text: In this appeal, all the arguments which had failed before the High Court were urged before us. Shortly stated, they are that the contract was void a for illegality and b for uncertainty and vagueness on two grounds

issues.text: Whether the contract was void for vagueness or uncertainty due to the phrase 'subject to the usual Force Majeure Clause'

anchor.surface_text: The agreement is said to be void because of vagueness and uncertainty arising from the use of the phrase subject to the usual force majeure clause . The argument is that there was no consensus ad idem

issues.text: Whether the contract was void for vagueness or uncertainty due to the words 'if necessary' in the letter dated November 30, 1957

anchor.surface_text: The next ground on which it is said that the agreement was void for uncertainty has reference to the employment of the words if necessary in the letter of November, 30, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: under ss. 32 and 33 of the Arbitration Act by the Court and not by the arbitrator in a reference under s. 20 of the Act.

arguments.claim: Clauses 6 and 7 are unlawful as they contravene the import policy of Government of India and the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1947, rendering the contract void and the arbitration clause not binding

anchor.surface_text: By their first affidavit dated July 31, 1958, the buyers contended that cls. 6 and 7, quoted above, were unlawful, as the liability created under them amounted to a contravention of the import policy of Government of India and the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1947, and the Rules made thereunder. They contended that, in view of the invalidity of the contract as a whole, the arbitration clause in the agreement was not binding, and that the agreement could not be filed.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ismissal of the petition, and the buyers cross-objected against the adverse findings and the disallowance of companyts. The appeal was heard by Tarkun

arguments.court_reasoning: s.21(2) engrafts implied term requiring permission; s.21(3) allows proceedings; resale not as agent under Sale of Goods Act s.54

arguments.claim: Phrase 'subject to the usual Force Majeure Clause' is vague and uncertain, causing no consensus ad idem and rendering contract void ab initio

anchor.surface_text: In the second affidavit which was filed on February 4, 1959, they added the reason that the words subject to the usual Force Majeure Clause were vague and uncertain, and made the contract void ab initio, as there was no consensus ad idem between the parties.

arguments.claim: Letter dated November 30, 1957 is void for contravening Import Trade Control Act and FERA; words 'if necessary' render it vague and uncertain

anchor.surface_text: By yet another affidavit filed on February 27, 1959, they averred that the letter dated November 30, 1957, was void, being in contravention of the Import Trade Control Act and the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act and the Rules made under the two Acts, inasmuch as the consideration was one forbidden by law and was likely to defeat the provisions of law. They also stated that the words if necessary in that letter rendered the contract void ab initio for vagueness and uncertainty.

arguments.court_reasoning: Sellers had absolute discretion under cl.6; amendment surrenders it conditionally if buyers need time; consensus present

arguments.claim: Bye-law 38-A is statutory under Forward Contracts Act; inconsistent with s.20 Arbitration Act, rendering petition incompetent

anchor.surface_text: When the case went back for retrial, the buyers filed their fourth affidavit on November 16, 1959. They stated in that affidavit that Bye-law 38-A was a statutory Bye-law of the East India Cotton Association, Ltd., Bombay, a recognised Institution under the Forward Contracts Regulation Act, No. 74 of 1952, and that s. 46 of the Arbitration Act was applicable. They contended that inasmuch as the Bye-laws of the Association prescribed a different machinery inconsistent with and repugnant to s. 20 of the Arbitration Act, the latter section was inapplicable, and that the petition was incompetent.

arguments.court_reasoning: s.20 applicable; court files agreement and refers per bye-law machinery via s.46; not inconsistent

arguments.claim: Petition under s.20 not maintainable as dispute on validity of contract/arbitration agreement must be under ss.32/33

anchor.surface_text: The case was heard by K. T. Desai, J.  as he then was, . On March 3, 1959, the learned Judge dismissed the petition as not maintainable on the ground that ,the dispute was about the legality or validity of the contract including the agreement about arbitration, and that such a dispute could only be considered under ss. 32 and 33 of the Arbitration Act by the Court and not by the arbitrator in a reference under s. 20 of the Act.

arguments.claim: Bye-law 38-A machinery leaves no role for court under s.20(4); no averment parties failed to agree; petition discloses insufficient materials

anchor.surface_text: By his order dated November 26 and 27,1959, K. T. Desai, J. held that the petition did not disclose sufficient materials, and that the sellers were not entitled to have the agreement of reference filed, or to have an order of reference made. Though he held that the Bye-laws of the East India Cotton Association, Ltd. were statutory, and that ss. 46 and 47 of the Arbitration Act applied, he was of opinion that s. 20 could not be invoked, because no action under sub-s.  4  of s. 20 could be taken.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the contract was not void for illegality. The agreement is said to be void because of cl. 7 of the agreement involves a breach of the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act.

holdings.text: The contract was not void for illegality because clauses 6 and 7 do not breach the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act due to implied terms under s.21(2) and permission requirements under s.21(3); resale under cl.7 is by seller for self, not agent of buyer per Sale of Goods Act ss.54(2),(4).

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the contract was not void for illegality. The agreement is said to be void because of cl. 7 of the agreement involves a breach of the Foreign Exchange Regulation Act. Reliance is placed upon s. 5 of the Act, which reads as follows

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.21(2) engrafts implied term that prohibited acts require Reserve Bank permission; s.21(3) permits legal proceedings but defers enforcement to permission; permission encompasses exemption; resale not agency.

holdings.text: Seller's resale right under cl.7 per ss.54(2),(4) Sale of Goods Act exercised for self, not as agent of buyer on notice, so no payment to buyer abroad.

anchor.surface_text: The contention, that on resale the price would have accrued to the buyers in the first instance, as the sellers would be acting as the agents of the buyers, is also incorrect. It has been rightly pointed out by K. T. Desai, J.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory resale by unpaid seller on notice not agency; buyer liable for deficit, not entitled to surplus.

holdings.text: Contract not void for vagueness/uncertainty under Contract Act s.29 due to 'subject to the usual Force Majeure Clause'; capable of being made certain by trade evidence.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the contract was not void for vagueness or uncertainty by reason of the reference in the terms stated, to the force majeure clause. Mr. Daphtary posed the question as to on whom was the burden of proving the usual force

holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Usual' refers to specific trade clause provable by evidence; distinguishes British Industries (no 'usual'), follows Shamrock SS (usual colliery guarantee); commercial docs construed broadly per Hillas, Adamastos.

holdings.text: Burden of proving content of 'usual force majeure clause' is for arbitrators.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion if the agreement is not void for uncertainty, that question would be a matter for the decision of the arbitrators.

holdings.text: Amendment letter of Nov 30, 1957 not void for uncertainty of 'if necessary'; sellers surrender discretion conditionally if buyers need time for licence.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, this argument has no force whatever. Under cl. 6, the sellers had an absolute discretion either to carry over the goods or to insist on delivery being taken. By this letter, they have said that, if necessary,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Context of cl.6 shows 'necessary' means if buyers delayed by licence; parties confirmed, consensus ad idem.

holdings.text: Court must decide existence/validity of arbitration agreement before filing/reference under s.20, per ss.32-33.

anchor.surface_text: To begin with, questions as to the existence or validity of the agreement are saved from decisions by arbitrators or umpires, however appointed. Since such a plea can only be raised in bar of an application by persons seeking a reference

holdings.reasoning_summary: Validity pleas raised in s.20 opposition decided by court; agrees with Div Bench.

holdings.text: Petition under s.20 Arbitration Act maintainable despite Bye-law 38-A; court files agreement, refers per bye-law machinery via Chairman appointment.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is no impediment to action being taken under s. 20 4  of the Arbitration Act. We may dispose of here a supplementary argument that the dispute till now is about the legal existence of the agreement

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.46 applies Act unless inconsistent; court performs filing (judicial), reference ministerial by sending to Chairman; Bye-laws prevail post-reference; s.47 general application.

holdings.text: Dispute on contract validity arises 'out of or in relation to' contract per Bye-law 38-A, even if existence challenged.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the words of the Bye-law arising out of or in relation to contracts are sufficiently wide to comprehend matters, which can legitimately arise under s. 20.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bye-law words broad enough for s.20 validity disputes.

holdings.text: Proper law of contract is Indian law, not lex loci solutionis (British East Africa law).

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, two such circumstances are decisive. The first is that the parties have agreed that in case of dispute the Bombay High Court would have jurisdiction, and an old legal proverb says, Qui elicit judicem eligit jus

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdiction clause for Bombay HC, arbitration in India indicate parties' intention for Indian law over presumptions.

anchor.surface_text: McCardie J. in Lebeaupin v. Crispin 1 has given an account of what is meant by force majeure with reference to its history. The expression force majeure is number a mere French version of the Latin expression Vis major . It is undoubtedly a term of wider import. Difficulties have arisen in the past as to what companyld legitimately be included in force majeure . Judges have agreed that strikes, break-

precedents.cited_proposition: account of what is meant by force majeure with reference to its history; expression force majeure is not a mere French version of Vis major and is a term of wider import including strikes and breakdown of machinery

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellants relies strongly on a, decision of McNair, J. in British Industries v. Patley Pressings 2 . There, the expression used was subject to force majeure conditions . The learned Judge held that by conditions was meant. clauses and contingencies or circumstances, and that there being a variety of force majeure clauses in the trade, there

precedents.cited_proposition: subject to force majeure conditions held vague as variety of force majeure clauses exist and no concluded agreement

precedents.citation: Scammell G. and Nephew Ltd. v. Ouston H.C. and J.G. 1

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel also relies upon a decision of the House of Lords in Scammell G. and Nephew Ltd. v. Ouston H.C. and J.G. 1 , where the reference to on hire purchase terms was held to be too vague to constitute a concluded contract. It will appear from the decision of the House of Lords that the clause was held to be vague, because no precise meaning could be attributed to it, there being a variety of hire purchase clauses.

precedents.case_name: Scammell (G. and Nephew) Ltd. v. Ouston
precedents.cited_proposition: reference to on hire purchase terms too vague to constitute concluded contract due to variety of such terms

precedents.citation: Bishop Baxter Ld. v. Anglo-Estern Trading Industrial Co. Ld. 2

anchor.surface_text: Our case is more analogous to the decision referred to in Bishop Baxter Ld. v. Anglo-Estern Trading Industrial Co. Ld. 2 , namely, Shamrock S. S. Co. v., Storey 3 . In speaking of the condition there, Lord Goddard observed as follows Abbreviated references in a commercial instrument are, in spite of brevity, often self-explanatory or susceptible of definite application in the light of the circumstances, as, for instance, where the reference is to a term, clause, or document of a wellknown import like c.i.f.

precedents.case_name: Bishop Baxter Ltd. v. Anglo-Eastern Trading & Industrial Co. Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: abbreviated references in commercial instruments susceptible of definite application especially with epithet usual

precedents.citation: Shamrock S. S. Co. v., Storey 3

anchor.surface_text: namely, Shamrock S. S. Co. v., Storey 3 . In speaking of the condition there, Lord Goddard observed as follows Abbreviated references in a commercial instrument are, in spite of brevity, often self-explanatory or susceptible of definite application in the light of the circumstances, as, for instance, where the reference is to a term, clause, or document of a wellknown import like c.i.f. or which prevails in common use in a particular place of performance as may be indicated by the addition of the epithet usual see Shamrock S. S. Co. v. Storey a , where usual colliery guarantee was referred to in a charter-party in order to define loading obligations.

precedents.cited_proposition: usual colliery guarantee referred to in charter-party to define loading obligations; example of usual term

anchor.surface_text: This was laid down by the House of Lords in Hillas CO. v. Arcos Ltd. 1, and the observations of Lord Wright have become classic, and have been quoted with approval both by the Judicial Committee and the House of Lords ever since. The latest case of the House of Lords is Adamastos Shipping Co. Ltd. v. Anglo-Saxon Petroleum Co. Ltd. 2 . There, the clause was This bill of lading , whereas the document to which it referred was a charter-party.

precedents.case_name: Hillas & Co. Ltd. v. Arcos Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: Courts should give meaning to commercial documents if possible; observations of Lord Wright on construction

precedents.citation: Adamastos Shipping Co. Ltd. v. Anglo-Saxon Petroleum Co. Ltd. 2

anchor.surface_text: The latest case of the House of Lords is Adamastos Shipping Co. Ltd. v. Anglo-Saxon Petroleum Co. Ltd. 2 . There, the clause was This bill of lading , whereas the document to which it referred was a charter-party. Viscount Simonds summarised all the rules applicable to construction of commercial documents, and laid down that effort should always be made to construe commercial agreements broadly and one must not be astute to find defects in them, or reject them as meaningless.

precedents.case_name: Adamastos Shipping Co. Ltd. v. Anglo-Saxon Petroleum Co. Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: construe commercial agreements broadly; not astute to find defects or reject as meaningless

anchor.surface_text: It is argued that by the application of the Bye- laws, the Court is left no powers under s. 20 which is being invoked, and that s. 20 cannot thus apply. ... described by Lord Macnaghten in Ghulam Jilani v. Muhammad Hassan 1 , and that this belongs to the second category there described, in which all further proceedings are under the supervision of the Court .

precedents.cited_proposition: three kinds of arbitrations described by Lord Macnaghten

anchor.surface_text: Reference was made to certain observations in Heyman v. Darwins Ltd. 1 . In our opinion, the words of the Bye-law arising out of or in relation to contracts are sufficiently wide to comprehend matters, which can legitimately arise under s. 20. The argument is that, when a, party questions the very existence of a contract, no dispute can be said to arise out of it.

precedents.cited_proposition: observations on disputes arising out of or relating to contracts including challenges to existence

anchor.surface_text: Auckland Corporation Alliance Assurance Co. 1 The learned authors observe, on the same page further But these rules are only in the nature of presumptions, and subject to the intention of the parties, whether expressly declared or inferred from the terms and nature of the contract and the circumstances of the case.

precedents.case_name: Auckland Corporation v. Alliance Assurance Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: proper law of contract may be presumed to be law of country where to be performed

precedents.citation: N. V. Kwick Who Tang v. James Finlay Co. 1

anchor.surface_text: See N. V. Kwick Who Tang v. James Finlay Co. 1 . The second circumstance is that the arbitration clause indicated an arbitration in India.

precedents.case_name: N.V. Kwik Hoo Tong v. James Finlay & Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: if courts of particular country chosen, expected to apply their own law

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, there is no impediment to action being taken under s. 20 4 of the Arbitration Act.

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal dismissed; all contentions of appellants rejected; contract held valid and not void for illegality, vagueness or uncertainty; petition under s.20 of Arbitration Act held maintainable; arbitration agreement to be filed and dispute referred to arbitration per Bye-law 38-A
directions: Agreement to be filed in court
